channel.title: The next fifty years
channel.description:
A series of lectures recorded in Autumn, 1967 at the American Institute of Planners Conference, Washington, D.C. The emphasis is on projected urban needs for the next fifty years, including city planning, housing, architecture, recreation, and transportation.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: Episode 8: Role of Business in the Future Society, reel 1
item.description: This week we present remarks recorded at the 6th annual National Conference of Plans for Progress, held recently in Washington, D.C. and dealing primarily with business-related aspects of future planning. Speakers: the honorable Walter Washington, the mayor of Washington, D.C.; civil rights leader Bayard Ruston; city planner Colin Buchanan; and German planner Gerd Albers.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Episode 9: The Urgent and the Important, reel 1
item.description: This week speakers examined the next 50 years in terms of the future of education; the minority group--its future mental health and problems of identity; America's health needs; and the issue of what increasing leisure time could mean to society. Speakers: Robert M. Hutchins, president of the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions; civil rights leader Bayard Rustin; William H. Stewart, the surgeon general of the United States; and Dr. Sebastian De Grazia, author of Of Time, Work, and Leisure.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Episode 4: A Future Filled With Change, part 1, reel 1
item.description: This program features a discussion of technology, population concentrations, and the expectations of youth with experts in the fields of physics, philosophy, literature, and jurisprudence. Speakers: physicist Herman Kahn, philosopher Emmanuel G. Mesthene, and writers Carl Oglesby and Claude Brown.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: Youth

item.title: Episode 1: Creating the Future Environment, reel 2
item.description: This first program highlights the themes of the conference and features remarks by Harlan Bartholemew, chairman of the conference and a professional city planner who has pioneered in that field since 1912; French economist and political philosopher Bertrand de Jouvenel; postmaster general Lawrence O'Brien; and biophysicist Dr. John R. Platt.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Episode 12: A Nation's Policy for Its Future, part 1, reel 2
item.description: This week, the first in a two-week examination of such areas as national policies research, needs for the future, the planned use of America's natural resources, new incentives and controls and a study of potential new institutions that might be deemed desirable during the next half century of development in America. Speakers: economist Lyle C. Fitch, psychologist Herbert Simon, and economist Joseph Fisher.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Episode 5: A Future Filled With Change, part 2, reel 1
item.description: A second program featuring a discussion on technology, population concentrations, and the expectations of youth with experts in the fields of physics, philosophy, literature, and jurisprudence. Speakers: writer Max Lerner, socio-economist Robert Theobald, physicist Herman Kahn, philosopher Emmanuel G. Mesthene, and sociologist Karl Gunnar Myrdal.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: Youth

item.title: Episode 10: Creating a New Standard of Life, reel 2
item.description: Near the end of the third day of conference presentations, architects and urban planners gathered to put forth their ideas on the shape of housing and urban development. This week, ideas for creating a new standard of life with man as the measure through the contributions to be made in housing and urban form. Speakers: urban planner Charles Abrams; architect and planner George Candilis; Jack Meltzer from the University of Chicago's Center for Urban Studies; and Heikki von Hertzen, head of Finland's Tapiola Project and administrator and president of Finland's housing foundation.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Episode 3: Prologue to the Future, reel 1
item.description: This week features a discussion of the culture of American cities, the history of American physical planning, and the development of political planning in this country. Speakers are urban historian John A. Burchard; urban design consultant Carl Feiss; Robert C. Wood, undersecretary of Housing and Urban Development; educator and author John A. Kouwenhoven; Leon N. Weiner, president, National Association of Homebuilders; architect and planner Victor Gruen; and journalist Grady Clay.
item.dc:creator: WAMU-FM (Radio station : Washington, D.C.)
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Episode 7: The Future American Society, part 2, reel 1
item.description: This program features expert responses to last week's speeches on the necessity and difficulty of planning for a future society. Remarks by James W. Rouse: an attorney, mortgage banker, and developer of the model city in Columbia Maryland; seminarian J.V. Langmead Casserly; and Dr. Richard L. Cutler, vice president for student affairs and professor of psychology at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. Rebuttals by Karl Gunnar Myrdal and David Bazelon.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Episode 12: A Nation's Policy for Its Future, part 1, reel 1
item.description: This week, the first in a two-week examination of such areas as national policies research, needs for the future, the planned use of America's natural resources, new incentives and controls and a study of potential new institutions that might be deemed desirable during the next half century of development in America. Speakers: economist Lyle C. Fitch, psychologist Herbert Simon, and economist Joseph Fisher.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

Speakers: the honorable Walter Washington, the mayor of Washington, D.C.; civil rights leader Bayard Ruston; city planner Colin Buchanan; and German planner Gerd Albers.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Episode 9: The Urgent and the Important, reel 2
item.description: This week speakers examined the next 50 years in terms of the future of education; the minority group--its future mental health and problems of identity; America's health needs; and the issue of what increasing leisure time could mean to society. Speakers: Robert M. Hutchins, president of the Center for the Study of Democratic Institutions; civil rights leader Bayard Rustin; William H. Stewart, the surgeon general of the United States; and Dr. Sebastian De Grazia, author of Of Time, Work, and Leisure.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Episode 2: Role of Art, Spirit, Science and Technology in the Future Environment, reel 2
item.description: This week we investigate the roles of art, science, technology, and the spirit--areas which you will soon learn are closely interrelated. Commenting on their various studies will be three distinguished experts in the fields of education, theology, and technological chemistry. Speakers: Dr. Harold Taylor, educator, philosopher, and authority on art; theologian Joseph Sittler; and Ralph G.H. Siu, renowned for his work in the field of chemistry and technological research.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Episode 11: Context of the Future...Youth, Tech, reel 2
item.description: Policy recommendations for the next half century will only be implemented by the youthful members of the planning community. This program is devoted to the ideas of a few of the younger experts, who will be giving particular attention to the underdeveloped areas of the world. In contrast, this week's closing statement comes from an elder statesman in planning: Buckminster Fuller. Speakers: architect and futurist Buckminster Fuller; architects Renato Sevarino and John F.C. Turner; and teacher Ann Schrand.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Episode 13: A Nation's Policy for its Future, part 2, reel 1
item.description: In this final program of the series, a continuation of last week's speeches dealing with the broad topic of a nation's policy for its future. Commenting on that topic: the honorable Orville Freeman, secretary of agriculture; Desmond Heap ,controller for the City of London, England; Kermit Gordon, president of the Brookings Institution; Irving Hand president, of the American Institute of Planners; and Dr. William L. C. Wheaton.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Episode 4: A Future Filled With Change, part 1, reel 2
item.description: This program features a discussion of technology, population concentrations, and the expectations of youth with experts in the fields of physics, philosophy, literature, and jurisprudence. Speakers: physicist Herman Kahn, philosopher Emmanuel G. Mesthene, and writers Carl Oglesby and Claude Brown.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: Youth

item.title: Episode 13: A Nation's Policy for its Future, part 2, reel 2
item.description: In this final program of the series, a continuation of last week's speeches dealing with the broad topic of a nation's policy for its future. Commenting on that topic: the honorable Orville Freeman, secretary of agriculture; Desmond Heap ,controller for the City of London, England; Kermit Gordon, president of the Brookings Institution; Irving Hand president, of the American Institute of Planners; and Dr. William L. C. Wheaton.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Episode 6: The Future American Society, part 1, reel 2
item.description: This week, a discussion concerning the necessity and difficulty of planning for a future society as well as an analysis of a new factor in American society: technology. Speakers: Swedish socio-economist Karl Gunnar Myrdal, author of An American Dilemma: The Negro Problem and Modern Democracy; and writer and social critic David Bazelon, author of Power in America: the Politics of the New Class, who argues that the individuals who staff industrial bureaucracies of the industrial order are part of a new socioeconomic class.
item.dc:creator: Greenwood, Bill
item.dc:subject: World Politics
